title:
Birth weight and risk of ischemic
heart disease: A Mendelian
randomization study
author: Au Yeung
author_address: School of Public Health, Li Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR, China
hypothesis: Effect of birthweight on later life cardiovasulcar disease and traits
rationale: The association of low birth weight and CVD may be confounded by many factors. MR could clarify the role of birth weight in ischemic heart disease
outcome_study: Nikpay 2015 myocardial infarction All ancestry both
exposure_independence: Said they did check LD, but do not give a value
limitations_overall: The genetic predictors of birth weight strongly predicted birth weight at genome wide significance, which reduces the risk of false positives. Confounding of the relation between genetic variants and the outcomes is unlikely because we used separate samples for birth weight and the outcomes which reduces the risk of chance associations generated by any common underlying data structure. Overlaps between the samples used to obtain genetic predictors of birth weight and their effects were not substantial. The samples used were largely of people of European descent and included genomic control to avoid any hidden genetic associations or confounding by population stratification. However, the estimates for IHD were not robust to the use of different cases-control studies.
limitations_pleiotropy: estimates for IHD and MI were not robust to the exclusion of potentially pleiotropic SNPs affecting height or to the use of more conservative methods
limitations_population_stratification: The samples used were largely of people of European descent and included genomic control to avoid any hidden genetic associations or confounding by population stratification.

title: Causal Association between Birth Weight and Adult Diseases: Evidence from a Mendelian Randomisation Analysis
author: Zeng
author_address: Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Xuzhou Medical University, China.
hypothesis: Effect of birth weight on later life risk factors
rationale: it is not fully clear to what extent the fetal origins of adult diseases hypothesis holds and it is also not completely known what types of adult diseases are causally affected by birth weight. Determining the causal impact of birth weight on various adult diseases through traditional randomised intervention studies is a challenging task.
outcome_study: Nikpay 2015 myocardial infarction All ancestry both
exposure_proxy: For these index SNPs that do not have summary statistics in the corresponding disease, we either replaced them with proxy SNPs that are in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with the index SNPs or imputed the summary statistics (Pasaniuc et al., 2014) for the index SNPs—both approaches yield similar results
limitations_overall: First, we acknowledge that there was a small overlap between individuals used in the EGG GWAS for birth weight (Table S1) and individuals used in the DIAGRAM GWAS for T2D (Table S11), suggesting that a small set of individuals are simultaneously used to obtain SNP effect size estimates for both birth weight and T2D. Second, for some complex traits, we had to use GWASs with relatively small samples due to data availability reasons. Third, like many other MR applications, we have assumed a linear relationship between birth weight and adult diseases. It is certainly possible that non-linear relationships exist;
limitations_population_stratification: Sixth, our study focuses only on European population, and future studies are needed to investigate whether our conclusions can be generalized to other human populations.
notes: They re -ran the analysis using different SNP lists for birthweight from 2013 and UKBiobank - reuslts did not change
